awd_titl_txt: EAGER: ISN: Detecting and Disrupting Illicit Supply Networks via Traffic Distribution Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) will enhance national health, prosperity, and security by contributing to our understanding of and ability to disrupt the online infrastructure that supports illicit supply networks.  Malicious advertising is responsible for exposing a large fraction of online users to malicious content, including content from illicit supply networks, such as those trafficking in fake luxury goods and counterfeit pharmaceuticals. These abusive services not only exfiltrate private information and cause economic harm, but can also, in the case of unlicensed pharmaceutical products, damage public health. This project focuses on developing methods to detect and disrupt these illicit supply chains by targeting the traffic distribution systems that enable them, i.e., the online hosts that are responsible for redirecting users from gateway pages to the final abusive service. Mapping these networks and ultimately taking down their hosts will increase the cost of illicit commerce, yielding positive economic and public health impact.  The award will provide support to engage graduate students in research with high societal impact.

The project seeks to understand, measure, model, and disrupt traffic distribution systems as well as characterize the effects of this disruption on the pricing of illicit goods and services. By devising multiple high-toxicity URL streams and automatically crawling these URLs on a daily basis from multiple geographical locations and multiple browsing agents, this project will enable the collection of a large number of traffic distribution systems as well as the abusive services that utilize them. The project includes the development of techniques for converting the collected network traces into directed graphs, the attribution and merging of nodes belonging to the same actors, and the use of these graphs for modeling the effects of takedowns in the presence of operational constraints. This research will discover and document how these illicit operations function, improve the automated detection of their abusive services, and provide data to other researchers on the operations of traffic distribution systems and their vulnerability to disruptions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Traffic Distribution Systems (TDSs) are a key enabler of malicious online content, allowing attackers to expose users to a wide range of attacks, ranging from malicious advertising and phishing to abusive services and counterfeit goods. These TDSs are online hosts responsible for redirecting users from gateway webpages, e.g., malicious search results or visits on compromised and malicious websites, to the final abusive service. TDSs allow cyber criminals to make use of division of labor and segregation of responsibilities where the operators of an abusive service can be different from the attackers who compromise legitimate websites in order to provide user traffic to the abusive services.

The research outcomes of this project enabled us to better understand the architecture of TDSs and how attackers rely on them. We designed and developed tools and techniques which allowed us to capture the interactions between compromised services and TDSs. Among others, we identified the cloaking techniques that attackers use to hide their TDSs from researchers and cyber-security companies and how mobile users are exposed to different malicious content compared to users on desktop devices. As a step towards mitigating this threat, we proposed a machine-learning-based classifier that makes accurate predictions regarding the redirections that users observe and whether they are part of a TDS.

Next to studying TDSs, we also studied a wide range of abusive software and services relying on these TDSs, including malicious web bots, sophisticated phishing kits, malicious and abused content on social media, and fake websites developed by cyber criminals to increase the search-engine ranking of other abusive services. For all of these analyses, we open-sourced the software that we developed as part of this project as well as the datasets that were collected using this software. In this way, the outcomes of this project allow other researchers to build upon our work.

The research work in the context of this project provided the opportunity to graduate and undergraduate students to conduct research in the broader area of malicious web content and defenses against it. Students that worked on this project developed research skills in network and systems programming, malware analysis and detection, digital forensics, data mining and machine learning, as well as experience with technologies such as virtualization, cloud computing, and crowdsourcing.


Last Modified: 09/06/2022
Modified by: Nick Nikiforakis
